One of them was 48-year-old Giuseppe Pecoraino, several years older than Salica and like him a resident of Gravesend. Another man with them, Giovanni Ruisi, was 33-years-old and lived in Bushwick. Neither of Salica’s companions is a confirmed mafioso, though the timing of the trip and the absence of women and children lends itself to the imagination. Other records provide an indication that Pecoraino, like Salica, was involved with Cosa Nostra.

Giuseppe Pecoraino was an incredibly frequent traveler, with immigration documents showing how in addition to his 1928 trip with Giovanni Salica, he traveled overseas in 1926, 1929, 1930, and finally again in 1933. Of interest is Giuseppe Pecoraino’s initial arrival to New York from his hometown of Palermo in 1920: he is listed on the manifest next to future Colombo Family consigliere Giuseppe Buffa, who came from Lilo Garofalo’s hometown of Carini. Most of the known New York mafia members from Carini joined the Colombo Family during the 1920s and later, forming a powerful clan-based faction that produced multiple consiglieri and captains. Boss Joe Profaci’s son Salvatore, a future captain, married the daughter of Joe Buffa’s brother Frank, a Carini-born member who would later join the San Jose Family.

These connections could play into a current belief that the D’Aquila and Mineo Families were once one Family under Ignazio Lupo that was split in 1912. Another common thread connecting both Families is Palermo boss Antonino Grillo, referred to earlier as D’Aquila’s Sicilian ally during the 1920s Palermo conflict. Grillo was a prominent maritime entrepeneur who also traveled to New York on multiple occasions between the 1910s and 1920s and there is evidence he was closely connected to three New York bosses from Palermo.

Antonino Grillo was Toto D’Aquila’s overseas ally yet he was the brother-in-law of D’Aquila’s local rival Manfredi Mineo and Grillo accompanied Mineo to New York when he initially arrived in 1911, whereupon Mineo quickly became a boss alongside D’Aquila in 1912. Additionally, Grillo accompanied D’Aquila’s predecessor Ignazio Lupo back from Sicily in 1922 after Lupo petitioned the Sicilian mafia to help lift a D’Aquila-issued death sentence that targeted Lupo and his allies. A 1910 trip to New York that predates the rise of Mineo and D’Aquila shows Grillo visited Isidoro Crocevera in Brooklyn, a prominent Palermitano member of Lupo’s Family.

Despite his marital relation to Manfredi Mineo, Antonino Grillo appears to be an unbiased Palermo powerbroker with a close relationship to Ignazio Lupo and Toto D’Aquila in addition to his brother-in-law, all three of them Palermitani in New York who served as bosses of the Gambino Family at different times. Adding to these complex relationships, one of Antonino Grillo’s local Sicilian allies in the 1920s Palermo war was Ignazio Lupo’s brother-in-law Francesco Motisi, the boss of Palermo’s Pagliarelli Family. Toto D’Aquila supported the two Palermo bosses despite having been at odds with both men’s in-laws in America. Manfredi Mineo was allegedly a lead conspirator in the murder of Toto D’Aquila in 1928 and D’Aquila’s loyalists joined forces with Salvatore Maranzano who engineered the 1930 murder of Mineo, meanwhile Ignazio Lupo quietly outlived them both and died of natural causes in 1947. All three men were alive and on the streets of New York during most of the 1920s, however, and available sources describe how the shared presence of these Palermitano men — two bosses and a former boss — was a source of painful friction that required Sicilian intervention.

Manfredi Mineo’s alleged switch from boss of his own Family to boss of the murdered Toto D’Aquila’s former Family in 1928 is further indication that a degree of fluidity existed between the two Palermo-centric Families and that political circumstances — especially warfare — could prompt a change in alliances if not affiliation. The multi-faceted relationships among the Palermitani in New York and Sicily put outsiders at a massive disadvantage when untangling these relationships a century or more later using a few scant sources. Though many Carinesi would later become Colombo members, among them consigliere Giuseppe Buffa and his high-ranking clansmen, the Carinese Lilo Garofalo in the Gambino Family provides evidence of the two Families’ shared roots.

Giuseppe Pecoraino’s documented relationship to Giovanni Salica of the future Gambino Garofalo crew and Giuseppe Buffa of the Colombo Family provides direct and indirect connections to Carinesi in both Families. Though Pecoraino simply lists Palermo as his hometown, “Palermo” is sometimes used as a placeholder for any number of villages in the greater metropolitan area; Lilo Garofalo uses “Palermo” on his own documents even though he was born in Carini. The exact area of Palermo Giuseppe Pecoraino comes from is not clear from the information available and all of metropolitan Palermo supplied members to both the Gambino and Colombo Families. Pecoraino’s ties to both groups similarly make it unclear which group he would have been affiliated with, neither does his residence in Gravesend where Colombo Family members lived alongside Gambino members. His apparent friend Buffa was with the Colombos and though Michael DiLeonardo didn’t know the elder Buffa, he was familiar with the man’s descendants and knew them to run a Brooklyn catering hall, showing ongoing intermingling between Gambino and Colombo affiliates and their relatives.

That Giuseppe Pecoraino arrived to New York with future Colombo consigliere Giuseppe Buffa, only twenty at the time, then eight years later traveled with Gambino member Giovanni Salica is interesting and indicative not only of Pecoraino’s likely mafia membership, but also a political purpose to Salica’s trip, much as the travels of other Gambino members during the 1920s were political affairs on behalf of Toto D’Aquila. That Pecoraino was connected to Buffa from Carini and traveled with Salica who was part of a group with Lilo Garofalo from Carini might be coincidental, but it is worth acknowledging, as is Giovanni Salica’s marital relation to an Enrico Garofalo whose relationship to Lilo, if any, cannot be substantiated.

Giovanni Salica’s fellow D’Aquila member Jimmy DiLeonardo would take another trip to Sicily in 1934, the same one mentioned earlier in which a possible Bisacquinese paesano was on the ship. This man, named Tamburello, shares a surname with not only a Gambino Baltimore member but also an elder Bisacquinese man who was photographed with Vito Cascio Ferro and capo dei capi Giuseppe Morello in the early 1900s. Immigration manifests and hometown connections sometimes show no significant information, signaling what could have been little more than a benign social or familial visit. Often with mafiosi, though, they provide us with a deeper look into who was traveling together, where they were going, and other factors that hint at a common purpose. This is especially intriguing when travel companions represent different Families, as was the case with DiLeonardo’s 1924 trip with Paolo Palmeri of Buffalo.

The third companion with Giovanni Salica on his 1928 trip, Giovanni Ruisi, was a native of Alcamo in Trapani province. Ruisi’s residence in Bushwick and other documented residences in nearby Williamsburg place him firmly in Bonanno Family territory and his hometown produced influential Bonanno members, Alcamo being the direct neighbor of Castellammare del Golfo where a majority of Bonanno members were born. The DiLeonardos’ friend Paolo Palmeri, an intimate of the Bonanno Family, was from Castellammare del Golfo. The Alcamese Giovanni Ruisi’s presence with two mafia-connected Palermitani from Brooklyn indicates he was no stranger to Cosa Nostra himself, though available records don’t link him to other members outside of this trip unlike his companions Giovanni Salica and Giuseppe Pecoraino.

In 1992, 64 years after Giovanni Ruisi traveled abroad, a young drug dealer named John Ruisi was savagely murdered by the Bonanno-linked Giannini crew in Ridgewood, Queens, another neighborhood where many Bushwick and Williamsburg Bonanno figures from Trapani eventually lived. Though the young Ruisi was only on the fringes of Cosa Nostra, his name may indicate he was a descendant of the elder Ruisi. If Giovanni Ruisi was a mafioso, he almost certainly would have been a Bonanno member which would indicate Giovanni Salica was traveling with at least one member of another New York Family. Though Giovanni Ruisi was young enough in 1928 to have crossed the FBI’s radar in later decades, he died in 1966 at 68-years-old and may have been one of many older Bonanno members who escaped identification.

One record suggests Ruisi was employed for a time as a musician, though this does not discount membership — a Bonanno member in Arizona, Russ Andaloro, was a high school band leader and music teacher. Another early Bonanno member from Sicily, Nick Guastella, was a sculptor. Old line Chicago member Giuseppe Priola worked as a professional musician and even performed in the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. These careers and hobbies defy our modern assumptions about “gangsters” but this type of unassuming Sicilian member was not uncommon in the early American and Sicilian mafia. We can’t forget either that they too took a blood oath, swearing to kill for their secret society if requested.

Giuseppe Pecoraino was a Palermitano with ties to Brooklyn-based Gambino and Colombo members, making it difficult to guess his affiliation between the two Palermitano groups in New York under Toto D’Aquila and Manfredi Mineo. His 1880 birth and natural death in 1941 keep his true status shrouded in even deeper mystery. The frequency of his visits to Sicily between 1926 and 1933 — a total of five — indicate he was constantly attending to affairs in both the United States and Sicily. What Giovanni Salica was doing with these men is unknown, but to quote Michael DiLeonardo regarding this era: “Sicily had a huge influence.” These overseas travels weren’t without purpose, especially when traveling companions were fellow mafiosi.

These early Sicilian travels by members of the future Garofalo decina like Giovanni Salica and Jimmy DiLeonardo bring to mind Gaetano Martino, who took multiple trips to Palermo in the mid-1940s where he spent time with Charlie Luciano and no doubt other mafiosi, especially during his year-long stay. These travels were clearly not independent endeavors, as evidenced by Philip Mangano’s connection to Martino’s activities abroad. Men like Gaetano Martino, Jimmy DiLeonardo, and Giovanni Salica are all part of a larger trend showing a sustained relationship between this crew and Sicily between the 1920s and 1940s.

Another Genovese connection with this crew comes from Giovanni Salica. The Salicas were marital relatives of the Trainas — these ones with the Genovese Family, not the Gambino Family’s Piddu and Mario Traina. Genovese member Nicola “Diamond Dick” Traina was a lesser-known part of the Genovese membership though his relation to the Salicas shows a trend among mafiosi wherein they don’t simply intermarry among their own Cosa Nostra Family, but with members of other groups. This can be seen today but also historically in Sicily and the United States, a great example in New York being the intermarriage between Giuseppe Morello and Ignazio Lupo. These “mafia marriages” along with direct blood relation, sometimes comingled, formed the nucleus of early Cosa Nostra membership and strengthened the greater mafia network.

As referenced earlier, the entry of Giovanni Salica’s son Louis into the Gambino Family shows further continuity between different eras inside the Lilo Garofalo crew. Louis Salica’s story is even more significant, though, as he was a two-time National Boxing Association champion in the Bantamweight division and also won a bronze medal as a Flyweight competitor in the 1932 Summer Olympics. Salica is an established name in boxing history but not the only New York Cosa Nostra member to have made a significant impact on the sport: three-division world champion Tony Canzoneri was revealed to be a Bonanno capodecina following his retirement from boxing.

The first outward sign of Louis Salica’s involvement in underworld activity came after his own retirement from boxing when he was arrested in 1945 for “conspiracy to bribe”, utilizing using his position as a Brooklyn carpentry foreman to extort workers in an organized kickback scheme. Salica was convicted in early 1946 and sentenced to eighteen months in prison. His success as a professional boxer complements the acting career of Gaetano Martino’s son Johnny, Salica’s Gravesend neighbor, in that they both achieved cultural significance as the sons of Cosa Nostra members from the same decina. One played a mafioso, the other became one.

One of the most obscure members of the Garofalo crew was Giuseppe Ingrassia, a native of Palermo whose relatives were inducted in Sicily. His brother Andrea Ingrassia was a Sicilian mafia member identified in the 1980s Maxi Trial that targeted hundreds of prominent mafiosi, though Andrea would pass away during the proceedings. Andrea's son Ignazio was another made member bundled into the Maxi Trial, belonging to the Ciaculli Family, but Ignazio Ingrassia absconded to America where he lived in New Jersey through the 1990s and 2000s until his 2007 deportation. According to Michael DiLeonardo, who knew the Ingrassias, Ignazio was married to his first cousin, the daughter of Giuseppe, though by the time of the younger Ingrassia’s arrival to the United States his uncle / father-in-law had passed away but this did not prevent Ignazio from networking with the Gambino Family.

Michael DiLeonardo revealed how Ignazio Ingrassia transferred his Sicilian membership to the Gambino Family and reported to his deceased uncle’s old crew under Jackie D'Amico, with investigators noting Ingrassia's close relationship to D'Amico's protege Frank Cali, a Palermitano-American who rebuilt the bridge between New York and Sicilian mafia groups before his 2019 murder. Cali was related by marriage to the Gambino “zip” faction and served on the Gambino administration throughout the 2010s. A 2021 investigation revealed Ignazio Ingrassia to be the current consigliere of the Ciaculli Family in Palermo, showing deportation did little to deter his involvement in Cosa Nostra politics. His recent arrest was part of an adjacent investigation into the nearby Torretta Family that revealed the visit from a Gambino Family emissary who was once part of the same New York decina as Ignazio Ingrassia under Jackie D’Amico.

Michael DiLeonardo had his own brush with these transatlantic communications after his marriage in 1985. Not yet a member, old time Garofalo crew member Joe Cusimano nonetheless sought Michael out after learning he would be taking his honeymoon in Sicily and asked that he deliver a letter to a mafioso in Taormina, the Sicilian resort town Michael would be visiting. This practice of hand-delivering letters is an old mafia custom documented throughout the organization’s history, though Taormina and most of Eastern Sicily have little historic Cosa Nostra presence. Occasionally Sicilian Families on other parts of the island have members in remote locations, though, even as far as the Italian mainland and beyond. Pentito Antonino Calderone recalled how members in Catania originally reported to a Palermo Family before Cosa Nostra’s governing bodies authorized them to form their own local group, Catania being just down the coast from Taormina.

Michael DiLeonardo did as he was asked and attempted to deliver Cusimano’s letter but learned from local residents the recipient had just recently died of old age and Michael couldn’t follow through with the task. The man’s name was Rosario Vitaliti and records confirm he died in March of 1985, the same year DiLeonardo traveled to Taormina. Interestingly this same man was identified by the Italian National Police as having met with former Gambino member Nicola Gentile in 1963 when Gentile visited Taormina. They also noted that Charlie Luciano was close to Vitaliti and the two men were observed together at the latter’s home when Luciano spent time in Taormina in 1951. Rosario Vitaliti was evidently a major figure in Cosa Nostra circles and though Joe Cusimano’s connection to him is unknown it’s clear that DiLeonardo’s would-be meeting with him was part of a larger pattern spanning decades.

The elderly Joe Cusimano was yet another Garofalo crew member with heritage in Palermo — his father had also been a Gambino member — making it difficult to map out his connection to Taormina. It’s possible the letter had nothing to do with Cosa Nostra but it’s an indication senior members still maintained old habits and saw the value in keeping their longstanding ties to Sicily intact. Joe Cusimano was likely one New York member among many in this regard even as late as the mid-1980s. Younger generations of Sicilian mafiosi are now maintaining their own relationships along the same lines and the old Garofalo crew has continued to play a role in these interactions.

The Old is New

Another man known to Michael DiLeonardo as having headed his grandfather's former decina was Salvatore Guarnieri, though Guarnieri held the position in an acting capacity rather than official. An acting capodecina can serve as an interim leader without an official captain above him or he can be used as a stand-in when the official leader can't attend a given meeting. The most obvious use of an acting captain is when the official captain is incarcerated, in poor health, or serving on the administration.

When Lilo Garofalo was elderly and incapable of actively running his decina, Michael DiLeonardo’s mentor Paul Zaccaria reportedly served as the crew’s acting captain for a period, though it would be Jackie D’Amico who assumed the official position following Garofalo’s natural death in 1986. Michael DiLeonardo himself would hold the acting captain position when Jack D'Amico joined the Family's ruling panel in the 1990s, with Michael later taking over as official captain of his own newly-formed crew. He eventually supervised members of incarcerated captain Daniel Marino’s crew, but Michael’s decina initially included men who similarly traced their relationships back to the early Gambino Family, like his second cousin Joe Delmonico and the Modicas — the son and grandson of Jimmy DiLeonardo’s old Sciacchitano friend with the bakery, Onofrio Modica.

Michael became a favorite up-and-comer under boss John Gotti and assisted the Family leadership, sharing baptismal relationships with Junior Gotti and serving as his closest confidant. The Neapolitan-American Gottis were purely a product of New York without the deeper ties that defined the Jackie D’Amico crew, but they were still leaders of a long-running Cosa Nostra Family and had to acknowledge some of the men who reflected the Family’s lineage. The Gambino Family under the Gottis included younger men with older roots like DiLeonardo but also elder figures who represented Family history in their own crews and factions.

In addition to utilizing his modern Brooklyn perspective, the 1990s Gambino leadership used Michael DiLeonardo as a liaison to aging Sicilian crews like the Mario Traina decina and he was involved in selecting Traina’s successor when Mario died of natural causes in 1994. With the blessing of the Gotti faction, Michael met with senior captain Joe Arcuri for advice on candidates for Mario Traina’s former position, a spot that had been filled for over six continuous decades by Mario and his father Piddu before him. Arcuri was a close friend of the Traina decina and the long-running crew was more familiar to him than it was to newer leaders within the Gotti faction.

After consulting with Arcuri, Michael was told Joe “Oxie” Marino, no relation to Daniel, was the ideal choice to replace Mario Traina and learned Marino had once been a prisoner of war, having participated in the Battle of the Bulge during World War II. Though Marino’s exact heritage cannot be substantiated, FBI
